title: Patriots Super Bowl LX live updates: Can Pats beat Seahawks to clinch title?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots aim for a seventh Super Bowl win, facing the Seahawks at Levi's Stadium, Santa Clara.
Drake Maye leads an impressive Patriots turnaround, improving from a 4-13 record last season.
Kick-off is scheduled for 6:30 p.m. EST on NBC, with live updates from Levi's Stadium.

title: Holy Cross dedicates court to Bob Cousy
author: Trevor Hass
bullets: Holy Cross named its home basketball court 'Bob Cousy '50 Court' in honor of the legendary player and alumnus.
Bob Cousy, age 97, attended the dedication ceremony at the Hart Center and celebrated with fans.
Notables at the event included Bill Simmons, Charlie Baker, and Karen Kenyatta Russell, Bill Russell's daughter.

title: Healey proposes eliminating statute of limitations for rape when DNA evidence exists
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Governor Maura Healey proposes eliminating the 15-year statute of limitations for rape cases with DNA evidence in Massachusetts.
The proposal includes preserving sexual assault evidence kits for at least 15 years and mandates testing within 30 days.
Massachusetts currently has the third strictest limitations nationwide, behind New Hampshire and North Dakota, without DNA exceptions.

title: Watch: Patriots share hype video ahead of Super Bowl LX
author: Trevor Hass
bullets: The New England Patriots released a hype video ahead of facing the Seattle Seahawks in Super Bowl LX.
Head coach Mike Vrabel emphasized team identity and effort in a motivational speech featured in the video.
Wide receiver Stefon Diggs rallied the team, asserting that no one believed in the Patriots' success.

title: Former employee at Mass. post office pleads guilty after secretly recording female co-workers
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Nicholas Testagrossa, 43, pleaded guilty to obstruction and video voyeurism for using hidden cameras at a Westminster post office.
Testagrossa hid cameras in the women's restroom, capturing videos without consent, and attempted to destroy the evidence.
He faces up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine; sentencing is scheduled for May 12, 2026.

title: Jewish groups sue Medford over values-based investment ordinance
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Jewish groups filed a federal lawsuit against Medford's values-based investment ordinance, claiming it mandates ideological divestment.
The ordinance prohibits Medford from investing in companies linked to fossil fuels, defense, or alleged human rights violations.
The lawsuit argues the ordinance violates Massachusetts investment rules by prioritizing ideology over financial standards.

title: Eight things Patriots must do to win Super Bowl LX
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots need Drake Maye to excel against Seattle's defense and limit turnovers to win Super Bowl LX.
New England's defense aims to pressure Seahawks QB Sam Darnold, who struggles under pressure with high turnover rates.
Patriots corner Christian Gonzalez tasked with containing Seattle receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba in crucial matchups.

title: Willie McGinest shares how his No. 55 became an iconic piece of USC, Patriots history
author: Colin McCarthy
bullets: Willie McGinest wore No. 55 at USC after a tradition started by Junior Seau and continued it in the NFL.
McGinest and Junior Seau both wore No. 55 with the Patriots, symbolizing a full circle moment from college to NFL.
Brandon Spikes continued the No. 55 tradition at the Patriots until 2013, initiated by McGinest and respected by Seau.

title: Snow totals: See how much your town received
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Essex County received the most snowfall, with measurements up to 13 inches in some areas such as Salisbury and Beverly.
The snowstorm on February 7, 2026, heavily affected northeastern Massachusetts, with significant snow reported across several counties.
Reported snow totals varied, with over 6 inches in Middlesex County and lesser amounts in neighboring regions like Norfolk and Barnstable.

title: For all he’s done, Mike Tirico will experience ‘thrill of a lifetime’ calling first Super Bowl for NBC
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Mike Tirico will call his first Super Bowl for NBC on Sunday as the Patriots face the Seahawks.
Tirico will handle NBC's Olympic primetime coverage after the Super Bowl, showcasing his double-duty broadcasting role.
Tirico, experienced in major sports events, voices excitement and gratitude for this Super Bowl broadcasting opportunity.
